column1: Abstractive Summarization: A Survey of the State of the Art
Hui Lin@University of Texas at Dallas
column2: Vincent Ng@University of Texas at Dallas

column1: Senior Member Presentation Track Papers: Summary Talks
The focus of automatic text summarization research has exhibited a gradual shift from extractive methods to abstractive methods in recent years
column2: owing in part to advances in neural methods. Originally developed for machine translation
column3: neural methods provide a viable framework for obtaining an abstract representation of the meaning of an input text and generating informative
column5: and human-like summaries. This paper surveys existing approaches to abstractive summarization
column6: focusing on the recently developed neural approaches.
